For Mandatory Physical Ed.
BY MICHAEL V OGELBAUM

Freshmen may soon be required to attend physical education classes.

Beginning with the Class of
'86, freshmen may be required
to take a semester of physical
education. A proposal calling
for a mandatory physical education program will be discussed
and voted upon by the Committee on Undergraduate Studies at
their March 4 meeting. If the
committee accepts the proposal,
then the Academic Council will
decide whether to implement
the program.
The proposal drawn up by
the Department of Physical
Education and Athletics calls for
12 weeks of classes, with one
two-hour class each week. One
credit would be given for the
course. All freshmen,excerdt for
those on a varsity team or those
excused by the Health Service,
would be required to participate.

The proposal cites four
purposes of the course: to
promote an understanding of the
nature and value of physical
exercise as a basis for lifetime
activity; to provide instruction
in areas of personal health, diet,
nutrition, first aid, and the
treatment of injuries; to improve
performance in a limited number
of physical activities and lifetime
sports; and to provide an introduction to the JHU Athletic
Center.
The program would include
a lecture series, sports activity
session, and fitness/conditioning
sessions. In addition, a swimming test would be given and all
those who dig not pass the test
would be required to take
swimming instruction.
Introductory lectures would

In a place where sitting and eating
are the two major physical exertions most
people engage in, a proposal for a stronger
physical education program must be
considered seriously. The Athletic Center
has proposed one semester of required phys
ed for freshmen, consisting of two hours a
week for a single credit. The program
claims the laudable goal of seeking to instill
in students a general appreciation for
regular exercise, and of providing a basic
instruction in first aid and nutrition.
Dean Hooker has outlined three
important questions in regard to the
proposal which will suffice for our consideration of it here; is it necessary, should it
be offered for credit, and should it be
compulsory?
Yes, some sort of increased orientation towards exercise is necessary. Most of
the bodies here are screaming for physical
activity of. any sort. The average existence
here is cyclical, and works as follows: up
at the crack of noon after a solid four
hours, down a few bowls of nutritious
Banana Whackies, run to class clutching
savaged intestines, collapse into a seat in
the back row, and fall asleep. After class,
perk up with a few Toblerones in Gilman
Coffee Shop, and onward until the final
stumble out of the Hut at four a.m.
The problem with the Athletic
Center's proposal in regard to the above
regimen is that it won't make a dent. Two
hours a week, even if it were enough to
plant the seed of appreciation for regular
exercise, is far too little to get anyone
thinking and planning with an eye towards
physical exertion. Most students would
probably tank up on Toblerones anyway
and come in late for those two hours a
week. If the program is to avoid being like
so many other obligatory courses for the
non-participant, something like an hour
each day of the week would be a lot more

N-L: Do you think the Dean's Office should inform you

Cone: My instant reaction is no. I think I should set the

the instructor set the grading policy. I want to stress,
though, that we don't have good feedback, we don't
know what our colleagues are doing. The course guide
should include more questions on grading procedures.
N-L: Do you think there is grade inflation in your own
department?
Cone: I think relatively little in my own department.
Those are the grades I'm a little more aware of. That's
got to be weighted by my own grades, I'm more aware
of my own grades. For me if there was a point of grade
inflation in my own past, I think I was more generous
with the curve somewhere in the late sixties and early
seventies. At that point I decided that rather than have
A's be some very super special grade, and have D's and
the whole range, that I'd confine myself mostly to A's,
B's and C's, and I also feel that if I'm going to have to
make discriminations like that, I'm going to make the
cuts where it makes the most discrimination, and that
turns out to be in the mid parts of the bell-shaped curve,
and not out at the wings. It's easy to say people way
out at either end get A's and D's; it's hard to decide in
the middle part. I'm aware that a lot of courses get
graded lots of B's and not many A's, not many
C's—that's the easy part of the sketch for me, 'cause
you're out in the wings. I decided that if we're going to
have grades at all we ought to make the cuts where it
matters more, and that means to come further in. So I
decided almost a decade ago to go a third, a third, and a
third: one-third A's, one-third B's, and one-third C's. I
know that when the final grades are finished, I ease off a
bit. It ends up with more B's and fewer A's and C's.
But my first cut is a third, a third, and a third. That's
what I tell all my classes, but then I become generous.
